item.description: The title suggest angry at bash but in reality the anger is toward myself. Find out more in the post.

item.title: Sorted equally
item.description: Here you go, Python at it's best. Never seen this construct: if-for loop. Python is a free bird, you can't catch him. Thanks for your contributions.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Stringy Column
item.description: Raku rocks!! Basic non-recursive array comparator in Raku worth checking. This is cute. Thanks for sharing and well done.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #314
item.description: It's incredible how you find the edge cases and then presented with choices. Kudos for your effort, keep sharing your knowledge with us.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Even more strings
item.description: Smart move for catching the edge case. Well documented solution and bonus DIY tool as always. Super cool, keep it up.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Count Any Zipped Column
item.description: Simply love the story from start to finish. Great naration and beautiful solution. Keep it up and well done.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 314
item.description: Master of one-liner, once again surprised us with variations. Well done and keep it up.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Monotonous Prefixes
item.description: Another week another creative regex in display. Enjoy and decode it yourself. Have fun!!
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Sort of Equal
item.description: When it comes to detailing, no one can beat him. There's hardly anything left for imagination. Everything is documented. Great work, keep it up.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: TWC314
item.description: I wouldn't say short as per his standard but agressive use of substr() would make you look at it very carefully. Cool work and well done.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Equally Sorted
item.description: A very special construct used, never tried it before: unless-else-redo unless. This is incredible. Keep sharing the knowledge with us.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 314
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Equal Strings" and "Sort Column" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 315
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Find Words" and "Find Third". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Regex
item.description: Special variable ${^LAST_SUCCESSFUL_PATTERN} in Perl v5.38. Find out more how this can be really useful.

item.description: Environment variable PERL_RAND_SEED in Perl v5.38 and how this gives you power in your own hand.

item.title: Subroutine Signatures in Perl
item.description: It's about the how you deal with default parameter values when it is undef or false in Perl v5.38 or above.

item.description: Interesting problem and then cool solution. Keep sharing such stories.

item.description: Ever Wondered How to Write Software to Control a CNC for a Common Task Like Flattening Wood? Find the answer in this incredible post.

item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: Announcing the Perl Toolchain Summit 2025!
item.description: This announcement comes a bit late in the year, but the preparations for the next Perl Toolchain Summit have been going on for several months now. Today I am proud to announce that the 15th Perl Toolchain Summit will be held in Leipzig, Germany, from Thursday May 1st till Sunday May 4th, 2025.
item.dc:subject: Announcements

item.title: #714 - Munging Data?
item.description:
Hi there,

Happy Idd to all the weekly newsletter readers who celebrate the festival. We celebrated Idd yesterday in England and I assume it is being celebrated today in my native country, India.

For me personally, the highlight of last week was the event organised by the Toronto Perl Mongers. It focussed on the new edition of the book, Data Munging With Perl (2nd edition). Unfortunately I missed the event despite registering for it. However, I'm told the recording will be available soon. If you missed it too, don't worry, you will be able to catch up soon.

Speaking of the book, it is one of those must read classics for every Perl programmers. I read it, when it was first released, and I highly recommend you getting a copy to benefit from it.

Last week, Gabor mentioned Ramadan seemed to have had positive impact on me as I started writing more frequently these days. He was absolutely right!. But now that Ramadan is over, I'm not sure if I'll continue at the same pace. That said, I truly enjoyed this little burst of writing. It felt like therapy to me. It allowed me to share whatever was on my mind at the time. And when I receive encouraging responses, it gives me even more motivation to keep going.

I wrote few pieces last week, all of which are listed below. Please do check them out and share your thoughts.

I'd also like to take this opportunity to thank, brian d foy for his incredible book: Perl New Features. I have shared my take on some of the topics discussed in the book, and I highly recommend getting a copy. The latest edition has been updated to cover Perl v5.38.

This edition of the newsletter is packed with positive Perl news, so take your time and enjoy.

Happy Monday!!
item.dc:subject: Editorial
